Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: A modular toolkit for rapid prototyping of capsule robots
Award.AbstractNarration:
From robotic kits to modular electronic learning tools for sale on the market, none of them offers miniature device building blocks. This I-Corps team proposes a modular kit aiming to provide the users with a tool to shorten capsule robot design and development time. It is similar to constructional robotic kits and modular electronic learning tools currently available on the market, but implements each module/device building block at the centimeter scale. The proposed toolkit is expected to have a significant potential for commercialization in the field of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education, where it can provide an engaging learning-by-doing experience to high school, undergraduate, and graduate students.

This I-Corps team has developed the STORM Lab Modular Architecture for Capsules (SMAC). As a modular kit for capsule robots, SMAC offers more than just rapid prototyping. It comes with a software environment as a medium for everyone to study, understand, and adapt its inherent open source knowledge into creative small-scale robots. Creating a miniature device with SMAC is as easy as combining snap-on hardware modules, while the software keeps track of any changes in the background and stays in sync. This feature is the key element of SMAC's modular kit. It drastically reduces the time required for hardware reconfiguration and software rework. The commercial impact of SMAC may be comparable to the National Instruments Data Acquisition hardware that has become the de facto standard of signal and data acquisition, beyond the traditional analog hardware prototyping.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to vet commercialization potential of a modular capsule robot that derived from NSF funded research for improving STEM education in middle and high schools. After engaging K-12 teachers and school principals from across the country, we found that an affordable and larger robotic toolkit is more attractive than having a small modular electronics for building capsule robots. During the summer of 2015 we have formulated a team consisting of two high school teachers (one teaching AP Calculus and one AP Physics), four undergraduate students, and one high school student to translate our cutting-edge technology into an affordable platform and lessons useful for K-12 schools, covering the Next Generation of Science Standard (NGSS) curricula.

Read more in the press release here (http://engineering.vanderbilt.edu/news/2015/valdastri-and-team-want-to-put-tiny-robots-in-science-classrooms/)

In August 2015, our educational robotic toolkit has been selected as one of the three winners of the Silicon Labs and DigiKey "Your IoT Connected World Contest". Eka Susilo, the Entrepreneurial Lead for this grant, received $10,000 in Silicon Labs Components supplied through DigiKey to expand the robotic toolkit and bring it to local middle and high schools. This also secured a key partner for the acquisition of electronics components.

Read more about it here (http://community.silabs.com/t5/Official-Blog-of-Silicon-Labs/And-the-Your-IoT-Contest-Winners-Are/ba-p/147023?sf11651109=1)

To the broader impact, STEM education can happen anywhere in any society outside schools. Through a participation in Nashville Mini Maker Faire, we reached out to some of self-taught, peer groups learning called themselves as makers. These makers held an annual event every year known as Maker Faire and we were selected as the top three finalist of Best in Show for gaining most positive feedback from visitors on September 12th, 2015, with our robotic toolkit.

The process of developing a business model in the context of the customer discovery framework has provided a better understanding of the commercial impact of future research could have in the field of robotics in STEM education. This customer discovery process, has helped project participants develop a viable business model for the educational technology they investigated during the present effort. Based on the knowledge provided to project participants in the form of a seven week course focusing on hypothesis-driven business model development through the customer discovery process, Eka Susilo, who has served as the Entrepreneurial Lead for our I-Corps team, is now in the process of starting a company to sell our educational toolkit.
